Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Biotic control of resource retention in arid lands: testing the fungal loop hypothesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plants and microorganisms cycle carbon and nitrogen between the atmosphere and the biota to drive the activities that they need to survive and reproduce. The role of plants and microbes in these cycles are well-understood in mesic (moist) environments but are unresolved in drylands. In arid regions, plants and microbes usually grow for only brief periods following rainfall events. During dry times, resources like carbon or nitrogen can be lost from the ecosystem and returned to the atmosphere, and therefore unavailable for organisms when the next rain comes. One mechanism for conserving resources occurs when direct exchanges between plants and microbes make water and nutrient use more efficient. For example, fungi in roots provide water and nitrogen to plants and receive carbon from plant photosynthesis. The proposed research will test they hypothesis that in arid lands, thread-like soil fungi connect plant roots to microbe-encrusted soils to more efficiently transfer and retain nutrients. This study will improve our capacity to predict the effects of climate changes on plant-microbe interactions. Results from this study will be shared with land managers so that restoration activities protect or manipulate the soil fungi to improve production and reduce degradation to arid lands. Workshops will be designed for school children and the public to increase understanding of the unique features of organisms in arid lands.

In arid lands, producers (plants and biological soil crusts) are spatially separated with patchy distributions and are temporally separated due to differential responses to soil moisture, and thus resources released by one may be lost before being accessed by the other. The fungal loop hypothesis proposes that plants and biocrusts are functionally coupled by fungi that transfer water and nutrients between them, reducing resource loss. Observations support the hypothesis, but experimental manipulations of fungi have not yet been conducted. This dissertation work directly tests the mechanisms and ecological effects of fungal connections between plants and biocrusts. First, to determine whether fungal connections between plants and biocrusts exist and if they enable more efficient resource transfer than physical processes, mesh will be used to inhibit root or fungal connections. Experiments using stable isotopes (N, C) will compare transport rates via fungi to rates via physical processes alone. Second, connection (mesh) and plant/biocrust removal treatments will be imposed to test whether fungal connections affect a) the individual performance of plants and biocrusts, b) net plant-biocrust interactions, and c) resource retention. These experiments will be replicated under two precipitation regimes to determine if the fungal loop shows context-dependency with respect to water, one of the resources driving production in arid lands. Understanding the conditions that enable efficient resource cycling will refine predictions on the drivers of productivity and resource dynamics in arid lands. Proposed improvements will determine which fungal taxa occur in biocrusts, rhizospheric soil, and within roots and how these fungi are affected when fungal connections with plants or biocrusts are intact or inhibited and under different watering regimes. Stable isotope probing will be used to identify which fungal taxa are active (versus dormant), and therefore most likely to drive resource transfers between plants and biocrusts. The primary goal of stable isotope probing is to identify fungal taxa involved in the fungal loop. Connecting fungal identity and diversity to resource transfers among producers is essential for understanding the mechanisms of resource cycling in arid ecosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Drylands occupy more than 1/3 of the Earth’s terrestrial surface and are major contributors to interannual fluxes in CO2, but how nutrients are cycled to support primary productivity, is poorly resolved. Drylands have unique producer communities relative to most mesic systems. These include diverse communities on the soil surface, collectively known as “biological soil crusts” which include photosynthetic and non-photosynthetic organisms such as cyanobacteria, fungi, algae, bacteria, archaea, mosses, and lichens. Biocrust organisms can fix atmospheric nitrogen to fertilize the soil, but how this nitrogen reaches the plant roots, deeper in the soil, is unknown. Plant and biocrust activities are driven by pulses of precipitation interspersed with long dry periods, so water is a key limiting factor that must be considered in what function each organism has in interacting with other organisms and the environment. The fungal loop hypothesis proposes that soil fungi facilitate the exchange of water and nutrients between plants and biocrusts in arid lands, supporting productivity and retaining resources in the biotic pool.

An important step in resolving the fungal loop hypothesis is to discover which fungal taxa are able to function in resource transfers. Using traditional sequencing methods, dead or inactive fungal taxa that are not able to perform the functions proposed are indistinguishable from the active taxa. The specific goal of this project was to compare the composition of fungi that were active in wetted biocrusts and plant rhizospheres against root endophyte fungal communities to determine which taxa are candidates to transport nitrogen, and carbon between plant roots and biocrusts.

To determine if the same taxa are active in the root, rhizosphere, and biocrust, we set up an experiment with field-collected C4 bunchgrass Bouteloua gracilis individuals growing with biocrusts. We used hydrophilic mesh to allow or inhibit fungal connections between rhizosphere and biocrust microsites. We used stable isotope probing (SIP) to provide fungi with heavy water that is incorporated into the nucleic acids when cells divide (active community). We extracted DNA from the soil samples fractionated each sample by ultracentrifugation to separate heavy (active or naturally heavier) and light (inactive or naturally lighter) components. Additionally, we surface-sterilized roots and extracted DNA to compare the fungi living inside root tissues to the active fungal communities in the soil using fungal ITS primers. Finally, we sequenced the biocrust fractions to identify cyanobacteria use 16S primers.

We compared the fungal communities among experimental treatments and locations sampled (rhizosphere, biocrust, or root). We hypothesized that the composition of active fungal communities would be similar in root, rhizosphere, and biocrust microsites when fungal connections were intact. The active taxa in all three microsites were the candidate taxa to transfer water and nutrients between biocrust and plants. We found dark septate fungi to be present and active in rhizosphere, biocrust, and roots and therefore, they may be the key taxa regulating water and nutrient transfer, if the fungal loop hypothesis is correct. We found no difference between the fungal connection treatments in their cyanobacterial community composition, suggesting the biocrust community may be less dependent on fungal connections than the subsurface microbes near or in plants. Identifying critical taxa may improve land management and restoration practices by ensuring specific fungal taxa are present in sensitive or degraded landscapes to support plant and biocrust productivity.

            This award supported a female graduate student learning state-of-the-art molecular techniques and downstream analyses. In turn, she mentored 3 undergraduate students and one high-school student. With one of the co-PIs, she developed the lab section of an undergraduate ecology and evolution course, incorporating novel research into the classroom experience by comparing growth rates of different soil fungal taxa when in competition. She also developed two teaching units for elementary students to learn about the importance of plant microbial symbioses for nutrient uptake and soil stability. Two publications are in preparation, and results have been shared at the Ecological Society of America Annual Meeting in August 2017.
